intro: Lasthenia californica, commonly known as the California poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its showy yellow flowers and hairy, lance-shaped leaves. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in coastal and inland areas. Its flowers bloom in spring, producing a distinctive, delicate appearance that attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies. The California poppy is also known for its hardy nature and ability to reseed itself, making it a common wildflower in the region.
